ast.name: first steps with turtle
ast.comment: Start from here to build a turtle script! #docsTurtle #docsTutorials

body.text: {priority:20}
Imagine that you have just received a new toy, **Logo** the turtle.
**Logo** is a cool little turtle that moves, turns and draws with a colored pen. Logo knows only a basic commands but we'll teach a few more tricks.
## getting Logo ready
The easiest way to start playing with Logo is to tap on `Create Script` from the hub, then tap `turtle drawings`. This template loads Logo and we are ready to play.
The `main` action contains 3 line of code. The first line is needed to wake up Logo and put him on the screen.
Then, we tell Logo to change the pen color to a random color. It makes the paintings more fun.
## drawing a square
Let's try to draw a square with Logo. To do so, we need to decompose the strokes to create the square into a sequence of forward moves and turns.
### forward

Now that Logo is ready to go, we'll tell it to move forward 200 turtle units. Unlike his real counterparts, virtual turtles are pretty fast and happens immediately. Since Logo always starts from the center of the screen looking to the right side, Logo draws an horizontal line to the right.

tip: TouchDevelop has a weird editor optimized to enter code. It only allows you to enter full words. To enter the code below, start by entering the `recycling` symbol, then `turtle`, then `forward`. Then use the number page to edit the distance.
{pic:turtlef}
### turning
Logo does not know how to move sideways but he can turn! Let's tell Logo to turn `90 degrees` to the left. We are drawing a square so we need a `right angle`.
{pic:turtleflt}
### moving again
Logo is pointing upwards and ready to go. We tell him to move forward by another 200 turtle units.
{pic:turtlefltf}
### turning and moving again
The square is shaping up but we need to continue telling Logo what to do. Let's tell him to turn `90` degrees and move forward.
{pic:turtlefltflt}
{pic:turtlefltfltf}
and one more time...
and one more turn so that Logo finishes exactly where he started.
{pic:turtleflt4:Logo painted a square.}
Congratulations!
### exercise variations
* Change the color of the pen before telling Logo to move forward. Remember you can use the `set pen color` action.
* Change the thickness of the pen before telling Logo to move.
* Change the distance pass in `forward` to 100 on each line.
## less typing and more fun with loop!
Telling Logo to draw a square was a lot of fun... but also a lot of typing! I can't imagine how much code if would take to tell it to write an octagon. Maybe there is something better we can do.

Did you notice that we told Logo to move `forward` and `turn left` 4 times in a row? What if instead of typing it 4 times, we could simply reuse the same code 4 times... This is exactly what we are going to do with a **for loop**.

All the code within the `for` loop will run on each iteration. The idea of the `for` loop is that variable `index` starts at `0` and gets incremented on each iteration until `index` becomes greater or equal to `4`. So `index` will take the value `0`, `1`, `2`, `3` and then the loop will end.
Let's tell Logo to move and turn. Since this will be repeated 4 times, it will draw a second square a little smaller since we move a little less.
We know we are in the for because of the double gray bar on the side.
### exercise variations
* To draw a triangle, we should tell Logo 3 times to turn left `120` degrees and move forward. Modify the `for` loop to draw a triangle.
* Could you tell Logo to paint a pentagon (5 sides) or an hexagon (6 sides) with Logo?
## spirals
It's time to try a new trick with Logo. This time, we'll learn how to draw spirals.
{pic:turtlespiral}
Drawing a spiral is very similar to drawing a square; the only difference is that we tell Logo to move forward a little more on each iteration and we let it turn much more times.
So how do we change the distance passed to `turtle->forward` on each iteration? One possible way is to use the index of the `for` loop. Instead of passing `100` to forward
we multiple 5 times the `index` and add it to `100`
#### exercise variations
* change the color on before each `forward` call.
* instead of turning `90` degrees, try turning less or more and see the effect on the spiral.
